comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Could be, but hay has to be 'made'(dried in the field) for some time after mowing and that is/was generally done by raking (hence 'hay rake') and piling in rows which were then turned with pitch forks on a regular basis until it was dry enough to cart and rick.
  Here the mowers are still evident, so the crop (which has a rather long stem for grass) has only just been cut and is now being bundled (not raked into piles) by the ladies. Also, it looks as if the bundles are tied (no way would that be done with hay) because they are being held at the top.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content:
This looks like a grain crop, possibly oats, to me.  There are three mowers and three binders. The heads used to be faced one way and the 'sheaf' bound in the middle. The man on the right seems to be in the act of binding.  Later the sheaves would be stood upright against each other into little ricks-to dry or harvest. I think hay harvesters wouldn't be so closely trampling over the crop; but the task here is to lift it from the ground fast.  All workers are together.

 It is noteworthy how well dressed girls showed up to help and reminds one of Burns' reminiscence 'I sat her down with right good will Among the rigs of barley.'

comment.author: 41996436@N08
comment._content:
Well that's a really interesting theory, but I have some reservations about accepting it.. .
  Firstly it's probably my old eyes letting me down, but I can't see any ears of grain on the stalks, secondly those don't look like neat sheaves ready for stooking (but they do look like flax bundles ready for the steeping ponds) and thirdly, Myrtle26 rightly points out that the harvesters are trampling over the crop.. no one would dare do that with a grain crop of any kind - you would thresh it right back into the field, whereas trampling would do no harm to flax fibres. And (I know this is a long shot) could that possibly be a linen factory in the background?
  Since my last posting I've asked fifteen people for their opinion. Unfortunately the only farmer who had grown flax had grown it as a feed crop for cattle.He said it COULD be flax, but he was not sure. Ten of the fiften said they just didn't recognise the crop at all, three said rather rudely that the photo was too indistinct to make anything out and the other chap said something like 'I've never grown flax, but this isn't hay and it doesn't look like any grain crop I have ever seen, and it IS Ireland - a land famous for its linen - so maybe it is flax.'
  Sorry, it's not a conclusive result, but so far I can't come up with anything that is more helpful.

It seems we have ruled out hay but the lack of heads of corn showing up also struck me as odd. Six workers are at stage one without stage two being visible.  I am from the far south and have no knowledge of flax harvesting, but if it is a factory nearby surely that would require far more produce than that grown in its back yard.

Much better, thank you.
 It isn't grain I'm certain of that, and it certainly isn't hay... it really does look like flax. The standing crop in the background looks like flax.
 If I had to put money on it I would bet on flax as a dead cert. Bearing in mind that there are more than seventy varieties of flax and the varieties grown now are mostly for fodder and not for linen manufacture, it might be very difficult to find a growing match for this long-stalked variety. But, having looked at a lot of photos of flax plants in the last few hours, I'm as certain as I can be, that this is ....... flax.
